Player data.name: Lev Yashin
Player data.bio: Russia's "Black Spider" participated in four World Cups, earned 75 caps playing for his country, kept 270 clean sheets and saved around 150 spot-kicks during his career

Player data.name: Sepp Maier
Player data.bio: The 1974 World Cup winner, who was known for his fast reflexes, kept four out of seven clean sheets in the tournament. Maier, otherwise known as the "Cat from Anzing", is the most-capped German goalkeeper in history with 95 clean sheets

Player data.name: Oliver Kahn
Player data.bio: Kahn shone in the 2002 World Cup, was named the tournament's best player, and was the first goalkeeper to be awarded with the Golden Ball. He was in the German squad for four World Cups, yet only started in one

Player data.name: Dino Zoff
Player data.bio: One of the great European goalkeepers, Zoff holds the record in international tournaments for the longest time without conceding a goal: 1142 minutes, between 1972 and 1974. He became the oldest ever World Cup winner in 1982 at the age of 40

Player data.name: Viliam Schrojf
Player data.bio: Played in three World Cups but most remembered for his performance in the 1962 tournament, when he was the hero of the Czech team that stormed to the final. However, he committed a couple of blunders to hand the game to Brazil

Player data.name: Gordon Banks
Player data.bio: England's greatest goalkeeper was in the 1966 World Cup winning team and made important saves in the 4-2 victory over West Germany. He was also responsible for the "Save of the Century" in 1970, denying Brazil's Pelé a goal

Player data.name: Gianluigi Buffon
Player data.bio: Italy's all-time record appearance maker and illustrious shot-stopper made his debut aged 19 in 1997. He has been first choice since 2000, and became a World Cup winner in 2006, where he only conceded two goals

Player data.name: Rüştü Reçber
Player data.bio: 2002 was Rüştü's year, playing an important role in Turkey finishing third in the World Cup

Player data.name: Rinat Dasayev
Player data.bio: The outstanding goalkeeper at the 1982 World Cup, who is still influential – he was a member of Russia’s bid committee for the 2018 tournament

Player data.name: Jan Tomaszewski
Player data.bio: Dubbed the "circus clown in gloves" by Brian Clough, Tomaszewski is most memorable for his performance against England in a 1974 World Cup qualifying match. He went on to have an outstanding tournament in Poland's finest ever World Cup team, being named best goalkeeper

Player data.name: Andoni Zubizaretta
Player data.bio: A quietly outstanding presence at the back for Spain in four consecutive World Cups, particularly in 1990 and 1994. His international career came to an end when he made an error in the 1998 group stage match against Nigeria; Spain fell in the first round of his last international tournament

Player data.name: Wesley Sneijder
Player data.bio: Twinkle-toed creator capable of playing in any of the attacking midfield positions. Cemented his position as star during Holland's run up to the 2010 final, scoring five goals and winning four man-of-the-match awards

Player data.name: Paolo Maldini
Player data.bio: Widely considered one of the greatest defenders of all time, and certainly one of the most long-serving. First played in 1990, made it to the 1994 final as vice-captain, and was captain in both 1998 and 2002. In all Maldini has spent more time playing in World Cup matches than anyone else – 2,217 minutes

Player data.name: Hans-Peter Briegel
Player data.bio: A former athlete, Briegel's fitness, pace and stamina saw him initially selected as a striker, until he was converted to full-back. In both 1982 and 1986 he was in the West German team which reached, and lost, successive finals – he conceded a penalty in the former, and was partly responsible for the decisive goal in the latter

Player data.name: Roberto Carlos
Player data.bio: "The bullet man" known for his powerful free kicks, speed and immense thighs. One of the best attack minded left-backs, he featured in three world cups and reached two finals, winning the second

Player data.name: Andreas Brehme
Player data.bio: Ultra-dependable, two-footed full back, free-kick specialist and penalty taker, who scored the decisive spot-kick in the 1990 World Cup final against Argentina

Player data.name: Danny McGrain
Player data.bio: No-nonsense defender known for his dogged, tireless blocking and rumbustious overlapping runs. Played with great distinction for Celtic and Scotland

Player data.name: Giacinto Facchetti
Player data.bio: One of the most effective defenders in the history of Italian football, Facchetti went on to win 94 caps for his country. He represented the Azzuri in three world cups, including 1970, where Italy lost out to Brazil in the final

Player data.name: Junior
Player data.bio: Leovegildo Lins da Gama Junior – simply known as Junior, played in two world cups. A versatile right footed left-back who considered midfield his natural position, he was a key player in the 1982 team which was considered the greatest never to win the World Cup

Player data.name: Nilton Santos
Player data.bio: Regarded as one of the greatest wing-backs in football history, and certainly one of the first. Santos made no appearances at his first World Cup, in 1950, but was a key member of the Brazilian defence in the following three and won twice, in 1958 and 1962

Player data.name: Ruud Krol
Player data.bio: Versatile left-back or centre-back who could also comfortably operate in midfield, Krol was voted into the all-star team in successive tournaments. In 1974 he played on the left of defence, and scored a memorable long-range strike against Argentina. Four years later he switched to sweeper and captained the side to a second final

Player data.name: Silvio Marzolini
Player data.bio: Handsome and stylish attacking left-back and Boca Juniors legend who played three games in 1962. When he returned four years later, the British press voted him the best player of the group stages

Player data.name: Dragan Dzajic
Player data.bio: A complete winger, whose dribbling, crossing and finishing were all impeccable. Scored a brilliant winner against England in the 1968 European Championship semi-finals. Pele named him among the six best players of all time. Would be considerably more famous had he not spent his entire club career in Yugoslavia

Player data.name: Bobby Moore
Player data.bio: Classy and composed centre-back famous for captaining England to their first and only World Cup success in 1966, and for a magnificent tackle on Pele during England's failed attempt to defend their title four years later. He played every minute for each of the 108 caps he gained

Player data.name: Franz Beckenbauer
Player data.bio: "The Kaiser", considered to be Germany's greatest player. The midfielder turned defender lost in the 1966 final – scoring four goals along the way – and in the 1970 semis, in one of the greatest of all World Cup matches. He finally helped the team win in 1974, doing so again in 1990 in a return as manager

Player data.name: Franco Baresi
Player data.bio: Although part of Italy's 1982 World Cup winning squad, Baresi didn't feature once in the tournament. Nonetheless, he went on to become one of Italy's greatest defenders. He captained Italy to the World Cup Final in 1994, where they lost out to Brazil on penalties (one of which he missed)

Player data.name: Daniel Passarella
Player data.bio: The central defender scored 22 international goals and captained Argentina to World Cup glory on home soil in 1978. Although he didn't play in 1986, Pasarella was the only player to feature in both of Argentina's World Cup winning squads

Player data.name: Elías Figueroa
Player data.bio: Considered as one of Chile's greatest ever players, who captained the national team when they qualified for three world cups. In 1974, he was named the best central defender of the tournament

Player data.name: Marcel Desailly
Player data.bio: Ghanaian-born French defender, whose reading of the game and ability to play a simple pass saw him work also in midfield. He won 116 caps for France and was a member of their victorious World Cup team in 1998

Player data.name: Marius Trésor
Player data.bio: The French defender played in the 1978 and 1982 World Cups, and scored four goals in international tournaments

Player data.name: Hong Myung-Bo
Player data.bio: The first Asian to play in four consecutive World Cups. The resilient sweeper captained his country on home soil at the 2002 FIFA World Cup, and led them to the semi-finals

Player data.name: Paul McGrath
Player data.bio: Often regarded by many as the most influential player Ireland had during their glory days in the early 1990s. The defensive midfielder played in the 1994 World Cup despite a painful shoulder injury

Player data.name: Luis Monti
Player data.bio: The only player to appear in two finals for two different countries: with Argentina in 1930, and the wnning side, Italy, in the 1934 World Cup. A rugged and occasionally violent centre-half, who also took a mean free-kick and had the deft skills to move into midfield later in his career

Player data.name: Fabio Cannavaro
Player data.bio: Intelligent and quick-witted centre-half who made up for his lack of physical presence with smart positioning and unerring tackling. Italy's most capped player with 136, and their winning captain in 2006

Player data.name: Laurent Blanc
Player data.bio: "Le President" was at the heart of the French defence in 1998, and scored the World Cup's first golden goal. He received the only red card of his career and missed the final after Croatia's Slaven Bilic convinced the referee he had been elbowed

Player data.name: Guido Buchwald
Player data.bio: "A monster of a man," according to former England forward Alan Smith, Buchwald was at the heart of the German defence propelling the team to victory in 1990

Player data.name: Ashley Cole
Player data.bio: Has played in 14 matches during three tournaments as England's first-choice left-back, whose dependable excellence has made the job of successive national managers at least a tiny bit easier

Player data.name: Frank de Boer
Player data.bio: Holland's most capped outfield player, whose inch-perfect 60-yard pass allowed Dennis Bergkamp to score one of the World Cup's greatest goals against Argentina in 1998. Excels also in management roles

Player data.name: Jose Antonio Camacho
Player data.bio: Reliable and rugged mainstay of the Spanish defence for a decade. Widely considered his nation's finest ever left-back

Player data.name: Philipp Lahm
Player data.bio: Right-footed left-back or defensive midfielder who marked his arrival in his first World Cup game, against Costa Rica in 2006, with a superb sixth-minute goal. Captained the side that reached the semi-finals four years later. In both tournaments he was the only German to play every minute of their games

Player data.name: Antonio Cabrini
Player data.bio: Made his international debut in Italy’s first match in 1978, and played every game of their next three tournaments, missing a penalty in the 1982 final. Now manager of Italy’s women’s side

Player data.name: Claudio Gentile
Player data.bio: Centre or right-back who was solely responsible for man-marking Diego Maradona during Italy's 2-1 semi-final win over Argentina at the 1982 FIFA World Cup, after which he famously quipped, "football is not for ballerinas"

Player data.name: Milutin Ivkovic
Player data.bio: Footballer and doctor, Ivkovic was probably the finest defender at the first World Cup, particularly outstanding in a 2-1 win over Brazil. Destined to be killed by the Nazis in 1943, aged just 37, for communist activities.

Player data.name: Maicon
Player data.bio: Picked in the all-star team for his performances at the last World Cup, which included the opener in Brazil's first game, against North Korea

Player data.name: Josef Masopust
Player data.bio: Energetic midfielder who helped the Czechs to the 1962 final, where he scored the opening goal in a 3-1 defeat to Brazil

Player data.name: Carlos Alberto
Player data.bio: Captain of Brazil’s 1970 World Cup team and scorer of famous Pele-assisted hammer-footed fourth goal in the final against Italy

Player data.name: Cafu
Player data.bio: Won 140 international caps. The only player to play three World Cup finals, winning in 1994 and 2002. Won 16 World Cup finals matches, a record

Player data.name: Josimar
Player data.bio: Scored wo goals for Brazil at the 1986 FIFA World Cup, but was unable to help his team from bowing out to France in the quarter-finals

Player data.name: Lilian Thuram
Player data.bio: The most capped French footballer was part of his country's resilient defence during the 1998 World Cup which only conceded two goals in seven games, and scored a match-winning brace against Croatia in the semi-finals. Named in Fifa's all-star team twice, in 1998 and 2006

Player data.name: Djalma Santos
Player data.bio: Considered to be one of the greatsest right-back defenders, he was named in the all-star team in three World Cups – 1954, 1958 and 1962. His place in the 1958 team came despite him being overlooked until the final, where he was outstanding in Brazil's 5-2 win over Sweden

Player data.name: Giuseppe Bergomi
Player data.bio: Played in four World Cups and was the baby of Italy’s winners in 1982, when he broke into the team during the tournament and started the semi-final and final. Grandfather of the squad in 1998, where he made three appearances at the age of 36

Player data.name: Paul Breitner
Player data.bio: Highlight of his career was in 1974 as a member of the winning World Cup team, even scoring in the final. Has also scored in the 1982 World Cup final

Player data.name: René Higuita
Player data.bio: "El Loco" will be remembered for his eccentric goalkeeping: from pioneering the gymnastic scorpion save, to running onto the pitch into the sweeper position, to scoring from set-pieces, and his shock of hair

Player data.name: Giancluca Zambrotta
Player data.bio: A left-back for club and country until Marcello Lippi moved him to the right in the build-up to the 2006 tournament (though he would still occasionally be used on the left). He missed the opening game in 2006 through injury, but thereafter was outstanding, scoring an excellent goal in the quarter-final against Ukraine

Player data.name: Jurgen Sparwasser
Player data.bio: Goalscoring midfielder whose five goals helped his country to bronze in the 1972 Olympics. Played six times in the 1974 World Cup, scoring the only goal in the grudge match against West Germany. “If one day my gravestone simply says 'Hamburg 74', everybody will still know who is lying below,” he said

Player data.name: Zinedine Zidane
Player data.bio: Zizou is considered to be one of the greatest players of the game. He won the 1998 World Cup, scoring twice in the final, and won a host of international awards including the Golden Ball. Now most known for his infamous headbutt and dismissal in the 2006 final, after scoring a first-half penalty

Player data.name: Johan Cruyff
Player data.bio: Lengendary Dutch trickster at the heart of their “Total Football” style as they reached the 1974 final, his only World Cup – he controversially and mysteriously retired from international football before the next one in Argentina

Player data.name: Lennart Skoglund
Player data.bio: The "swaying corn-cob" played as a forward when Sweden finished third in 1950, and as a left winger in the host Sweden side that stormed to the final in 1958

Player data.name: Hristo Stoichkov
Player data.bio: Hero of Bulgaria's run to the semi-finals in 1994, and finishing joint top-scorer with six goals including a corker against Mexico in the second round

Player data.name: Mario Zagallo
Player data.bio: The only man with four World Cup winners' medals in his trophy cabinet, having twice won as a technical left-winger or forward, before moving into management and winning again in 1970. Went on the bench as technical director in 1994. He became a manager again, leading Brazil to the final in 1998

Player data.name: Paco Gento
Player data.bio: A member of Real Madrid's European Cup-hogging team of the 1950s and 60s, Gento was a pacey and creative winger with a glorious left foot, playing at the 1962 and 1966 World Cups

Player data.name: Zoltan Czibor
Player data.bio: One of the Magical Magyars that shook the football world in the 1950s, Czibor could play on the left or up front. He scored three goals in the 1954 World Cup, including one in the final where Hungary lost for the first time in two years, before prematurely ending his international career by defecting to play in Spain

Player data.name: Tomas Brolin
Player data.bio: The Swedish midfielder was at his peak when he scored three goals in the 1994 World Cup

Player data.name: Gheorge Hagi
Player data.bio: Romania's greatest ever player, the Maradona of the Carpathians shone most brightly in 1994, scoring a fantastic goal against Colombia, and in a famous second-round victory over Argentina, as Romania reached the quarter-finals before losing to Sweden on penalties

Player data.name: Jay-Jay Okocha
Player data.bio: Attacking midfielder who represented Nigeria for 13 years and went to three World Cups

Player data.name: Zico
Player data.bio: Never a World Cup winner, but a brilliant creative and goalscoring midfielder, and member of the fondly-remembered 1982 Brazil side

Player data.name: Lothar Matthäus
Player data.bio: The German technocratic midfielder played in five World Cups, from 1982 to 1998 – fitting a record total of 25 games under his belt

Player data.name: Michel Platini
Player data.bio: The playmaker is regarded as France's greatest ever player. In the three world cups he featured in, he reached two semi-finals, losing out on both occasions to West Germany

Player data.name: Alain Giresse
Player data.bio: The intelligent playmaker was part of France's "magic square" in midfield and was at the top of his game in the 1980s, when the French national team made it to fourth place in 1982, and third place in the 1986 World Cup

Player data.name: Xavi
Player data.bio: Considered to be one of the greatest midfielders, Xavi has won more trophies than any other Spanish player in history. He was key to the team's victory in the 2010 World Cup

Player data.name: Bobby Charlton
Player data.bio: Blessed with a ferocious strike and exceptional vision, Charlton was a key member of England's World Cup winning side in 1966. He went on to win the Golden Ball later that year

Player data.name: Branko Zebec
Player data.bio: Outstanding left-sided player, either on the wing or at full-back, although he would also play in midfield. He played when Yugoslavia twice reached the quarter-finals in the 1950s, and was later to manage Bayern Munich

Player data.name: Obdulio Varela
Player data.bio: Captain of the World Cup-winning Uruguayan team in 1950, Varela is considered to be one of the greatest holding midfielders. The national team didn't lose a single World Cup match when he was on the field

Player data.name: Matthias Sindelar
Player data.bio: Known as the 'Mozart of football', he captained Austria in 1934 World Cup. His dribbling and creativity saw him voted Austria's best footballer of the 20th Century in 1999

Player data.name: Juan Alberto Schiaffino
Player data.bio: Schiaffino played for both Uruguay and Italy, although only for the former at a World Cup. His creativity and passing ability were key factors in Uruguay's success in 1950

Player data.name: Helmut Rahn
Player data.bio: “The kind of muscular, bulldozing rightwinger once famous in British football but now seldom found anywhere” who boasted “pace, power and a fearsome right-footed drive”, according to the Guardian's obituary. Got two goals and an assist as the Germans came back from 2-0 to beat Hungary in the 1954 final. Having taken a couple of years out of the game, mainly spent getting drunk, returned to a starring role again as the Germans reached the semi-finals in 1958

Player data.name: Alcides Ghiggia
Player data.bio: Fast-running, mazy-dribbling winger for Uruguay and scorer of the winning goal in the 1950 final, where he also claimed an assist for his country's opener.

Player data.name: Nils Liedholm
Player data.bio: Captain of the 1958 national squad, at the age of 36 he became the oldest player to have scored a goal in a World Cup final

Player data.name: Ruud Gullit
Player data.bio: The Dutch Total Football player had a glittering club career and was key in the national team that won Euro '88. However, he was part of a team that underperformed in the World Cup, despite being among the favourites

Player data.name: Paul Gascoigne
Player data.bio: Gazza will be best remembered for crying after he received a yellow card in the semi-finals against West Germany, meaning he would miss the final. His England side were eventually knocked out on penalties, but his reputation was massively enhanced following a string of fine performances and a set-piece assist for David Platt's second-round winner against Belgium

Player data.name: Grzegorz Lato
Player data.bio: Lightning-fast winger who had a massive impact in 1974, scoring seven goals – failing to mark in only one game – as Poland took third place. He was still around as they equalled that achievement in 1982

Player data.name: Carlos Peucelle
Player data.bio: Creative winger and forward who was nicknamed Barullo – mayhem – because of his tendency to scorn prescribed tactics and float across the pitch wreaking havoc on opposition defences. Scored three goals as Argentina reached – and then lost – the 1930 final

Player data.name: José Andrade
Player data.bio: Former professional drummer, and star of Uruguay's dominant team of the 1920s, winning two Olympic golds and then the first World Cup. His nephew, Víctor Rodríguez Andrade, was a World Cup winner in 1950

Player data.name: Johan Neeskens
Player data.bio: Considered to be one of the greatest Dutch midfielders, nicknamed "Johann the second" after Cruyff retired. Neeskens was instrumental in the Total Football 1974 Netherlands team

Player data.name: Roberto Rivelino
Player data.bio: Famous for his moustache and for perfecting the "flip flap" move, the "Atomic Kick" was part of the 1970 Brazil World Cup winning team

Player data.name: Zvonimir Boban
Player data.bio: Supremely gifted midfielder who was the creative genius of Croatia's 1998 team, which finished third

Player data.name: Ariel Ortega
Player data.bio: Tricky dribbler who added creativity and a spark of unpredictability to Argentina's midfield in two World Cups (in 1994 he only played one match, Argentina's last), trying his sparky best to fill Diego Maradona's boots. Memorably sent off for head-butting Edwin van der Sar in 1998

Player data.name: Jairzinho
Player data.bio: His bursts of speed and shooting were a highlight of the 1970 World Cup. Jairzinho was the only player to score in every round including the final, hence his apt nickname "The Hurricane"

Player data.name: Garrincha
Player data.bio: The "Little Bird" was inventive and a talented dribbler of the ball. He was named player of the 1962 tournament in Chile, leading newspaper headlines to ask: "what planet is Garrincha from?"

Player data.name: Zbigniew Boniek
Player data.bio: First included in the 1978 World Cup as a 22-year-old, he was known for his blistering pace and dribbling technique. Won a bronze medal in World Cup 1982 when Poland beat France for third place

Player data.name: Cristiano Ronaldo
Player data.bio: Winking villain as Portugal knocked out England in 2006 on their way to semi-final defeat to France, and man of the match in all three of Portugal's group games three years later, before they were eliminated by the eventual winners, Spain, in the round of 16

Player data.name: David Beckham
Player data.bio: Dead-eye set-piece specialist and crosser extraordinaire whose first World Cup ended acrimoniously with a red card against Argentina in the round of 16 – he gained revenge with the decisive penalty four years later

Player data.name: Brian Laudrup
Player data.bio: A constant thorn in the side of his opposition, Laudrup guided Denmark to the quarter-finals of the 1998 FIFA World Cup. Despite losing to eventual finalists Brazil, Laudrup scored two goals and three assists

Player data.name: Luis Figo
Player data.bio: A right-winger who had everything – he could take the ball down the wing, cross, cut inside, shoot, pass, and cajole and inspire his team-mates to excellence. A member of Fifa's all-star team in 2006

Player data.name: Rob Rensenbrink
Player data.bio: Forced to play in midfield because of the presence of Cruyff in his favoured left-wing spot, Rensenbrink nevertheless excelled, though he was forced off at half-time in the final by injury. He was freed to showcase his dribbling skills four years later, with Cruyff absent, and scored five goals as Holland returned to the final, where he hit the post when he might have equalised in the last minute

Player data.name: Leonardo
Player data.bio: Intelligent, crafty wide midfielder or playmaker, linguist and polymath who played four times in 1994 – every minute until his tournament was ended by a red card for elbowing the USA's Tab Ramos in the head – and in all of Brazil's games as they reached but lost the final in 1998

Player data.name: Ronaldinho
Player data.bio: Big-toothed, absurdly talented tricksome left-sided forward who formed part of the attacking trident – alongside Ronaldo and Rivaldo – that took Brazil to glory in 2002.

Player data.name: Jan Ceulemans
Player data.bio: Lanky but ace Belgian midfielder who played in 1982 – fondly remembered for a killer assist againt Hungary – and 1986, when he scored three times, and 1990 aged 33

Player data.name: Pelé
Player data.bio: Won in 1958, scoring a hat-trick in the semi-finals aged 17, in 1962, despite missing most of the tournament through injury, and in 1970. Scored 77 goals in 92 internationals

Player data.name: Diego Maradona
Player data.bio: Was twice kicked out of the tournament, once literally, by Italy's Claudio Gentile in 1982, and once after failing a dope test in 1994. In between he was the squat, skilful controversy-magnet that dragged his team to victory in 1986, and back to the final four years later

Player data.name: Just Fontaine
Player data.bio: Born and raised in Morocco, Fontaine was a spectacularly prolific striker for France who managed 13 goals in a single tournament, a record unlikely ever to be broken

Player data.name: Gerd Müller
Player data.bio: Der Bomber was the ultimate penalty-area predator, scorer of 68 goals in 62 games for West Germany, scoring 10 goals in 1970, and winning in 1974

Player data.name: Ronaldo
Player data.bio: A winner in 1994 and 2002, and a member of the team that reached the final in 1998 (if not, famously, the one that played in the final itself)

Player data.name: Gary Lineker
Player data.bio: Bandage-armed top-scorer in 1986, though he will always be haunted by a late miss against Argentina, Lineker returned in 1990 to score four goals as England reached the semi-final, where they lost to Germany on penalties

Player data.name: Paolo Rossi
Player data.bio: Rossi will be best remembered for controversially emerging from suspension to score four goals at the 1982 World Cup, including a memorable finish in the final against Germany, as the Azzurri won their third title

Player data.name: Mario Kempes
Player data.bio: El Matador was top scorer as Argentina won on home soil in 1978, when he won the Golden Ball and the Golden Boot. Also played in 1974 and 1982

Player data.name: Teófilo Cubillas
Player data.bio: The greatest ever Peruvian footballer, who dragged his team to the quarter-finals in 1970 and 1978, when he scored a brace against Scotland and a hat-trick against Iran. Also played in 1982, when Peru were eliminated in the group stage

Player data.name: Lionel Messi
Player data.bio: Despite being this generation's greatest player, winning the Golden Ball four times and being Barcelona's all-time top scorer by the age of 24, football fans have been frustrated by the playmaker's performance on the world stage so far. Messi made it to the 2006 World Cup after being out of action for 2 months with an injury, but was the tournament's youngest goal-scorer when he scored Argentina's final goal in their 6-0 victory against Serbia and Montenegro. In 2010, he donned Argentina's No10 shirt for the first time in a major tournament

Player data.name: Hector Castro
Player data.bio: The striker had accidentally amputated his right forearm with an electric saw when he was 13, yet went into the history books for scoring Uruguay's fourth goal against Argentina in the first ever World Cup final in 1930

Player data.name: Leonidas
Player data.bio: Played for Brazil in 1934 (though he only played once, scoring against Spain) and 1938, when he was the tournament’s top scorer, with seven goals in four appearances. Regarded as the inventor of the bicycle kick

Player data.name: Ademir
Player data.bio: The 1950 Golden Boot winner and one of Brazil's best centre-forwards, "Queixada" (Jaw) as he was nicknamed, had incredible speed and was impossible for defenders to mark

Player data.name: Fritz Walter
Player data.bio: Captain of the West Germany team that won in 1954, playing alongside his brother Ottmar. Over time he changed from an all-out goalscorer into more of a creator, until he suffered a career-ending injury in the 1958 semi-final. Kaiserslautern’s stadium is named after him

Player data.name: Max Morlock
Player data.bio: A popular German player in the 50s and early 60s, he was in West Germany’s 1954 World Cup winning team, scoring his side’s first goal in the final. He scored 21 goals and gained 26 international caps

Player data.name: Gunnar Gren
Player data.bio: One of Milan’s famous Gre-No-Li trio of Swedish forwards. Played, aged 37, for Sweden in 1958 as they reached the final, scoring against West Germany in the semis, even though he was in semi-retirement at the time, playing in the Swedish second division

Player data.name: Ferenc Bene
Player data.bio: Bene dazzled in the Hungarian 1966 World Cup squad, and had scored 36 goals at an international level

Player data.name: Romário
Player data.bio: The clinical and stocky striker is widely regarded as one of the greatest marksmen of all time. Pace and skill in abundance, the powerful Brazilian's greatest World Cup hour came in 1994, where his five goals helped Brazil on their way to a fourth World Cup win. Was named the best player of the tournament

Player data.name: Roberto Baggio
Player data.bio: The only Italian to score in three world cups, the 'divine ponytail' was famous for his technical ability and supreme vision. But he was also responsible for a decisive penalty miss in the 1994 World Cup Final, which handed the world cup to Brazil

Player data.name: Salvatore Schillaci
Player data.bio: "Toto" was a passionate and tenacious striker who emerged from obscurity to win a goggle-eyed Golden Boot at Italia 90, scoring six goals in a remarkable tournament

Player data.name: Eusébio
Player data.bio: The Mozambique-born "Black Panther" has been the most famous name in the history of Portuguese football and was one of the stars of the 1966 tournament, where he scored nine goals before Portugal lost to England in the quarter-finals

Player data.name: Sandor Kocsis
Player data.bio: Kocsis was best known for his heading ability. Nicknamed 'the man with the golden head', the striker steered his country to the 1954 world cup final, scoring an emphatic 11 goals overall

Player data.name: Roger Milla
Player data.bio: At 38, Milla was the star of Cameroon's 1990 World Cup team, with his four goals helping his nation to become the first African team to reach a World Cup quarter-final. The striker was most famous for his elaborate goal celebrations which involved him running to the corner flag and performing an elaborate dance – an iconic image of Italia 90

Player data.name: Karl-Heinz Rummenigge
Player data.bio: "Kalle" was European footballer of the year and twice World Cup runner-up in 1982 and 1986. He made a memorable contribution coming off the bench in the classic 1982 semi-final against France, where West Germany came from 3-1 down to equalise, then beat, France in penalties

Player data.name: Dennis Bergkamp
Player data.bio: The elegant Dutchman played in two World Cups, despite a fear of flying, and scored twice in the 1994 finals. He was selected for the all-star team four years later as Holland reached the semis. His goal against Argentina is considered to be one of the best World Cup goals ever

Player data.name: Ferenc Puskas
Player data.bio: Widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time. He scored 84 goals in 85 international matches for Hungary  and was a World Cup finalist in 1954

Player data.name: Uwe Seeler
Player data.bio: Diminutive striker who never won a World Cup, despite playing for West Germany in four of them, but is the only man ever to score two or more goals in each of four World Cups. No striker has spent more time on the pitch at the World Cup. Scored against England in 1970 with the back of his head. Immortalised with a giant statue of his right foot outside HSV's stadium in Hamburg

Player data.name: Florian Albert
Player data.bio: Classy forward who shared the Golden Boot in 1962, and played again, to somewhat less telling effect, four years later

Player data.name: Oldrich Nejedly
Player data.bio: Top scorer in 1934, scoring five times, and returned in 1938 to score another two before sustaining a career-ending leg injury

Player data.name: Geoff Hurst
Player data.bio: Hat-trick-scoring hero of England's sole World Cup-winning side in 1966. Played - and scored - in the tournament four years later as England lost to West Germany in the quarter-finals

Player data.name: Tostao
Player data.bio: Represented Brazil in two World Cups, winning the tournament in 1970, before becoming a doctor

Player data.name: Diego Forlan
Player data.bio: A striker of the highest calibre, whatever Manchester United fans might say, Forlan has thrived whilst representing Uruguay at the World Cup. He finished the 2010 tournament as the official best player and joint top goalscorer alongside Germany's Thomas Muller

Player data.name: Preben Elkjaer
Player data.bio: The lanky, rumbustious star of Denmark’s stylish side in 1986, who scored once against Scotland and three times against Uruguay. Also remembered for two European Championship penalty misses

Player data.name: Silvio Piola
Player data.bio: Prolific striker who scored twice in the 1958 final and would surely have further cemented his fame but for the Second World War

Player data.name: Miroslav Klose
Player data.bio: A pure and simple goal machine and the only player to have scored at least four goals in three separate World Cups. Only second to Ronaldo on the all-time World Cup top scorer list, with 15 goals (joint position with Gerd Muller)

Player data.name: Giuseppe Meazza
Player data.bio: Elegant Italian forward who won in both 1934 and 1938. Famously converted a penalty against Brazil in the 1938 semi-finals even though his shorts fell down as he was about to kick the ball

Player data.name: Davor Suker
Player data.bio: Skilful and unpredictable forward who led the line as Croatia - competing in their first World Cup - finished third. Golden Boot winner with six goals in that tournament

Player data.name: Marius Tresor
Player data.bio: A calm, classy defender for Marseille and France, best remembered for his goal in the thrilling 3-3 draw with West Germany in 1982. Named by Pele as one of the top 125 greatest living footballers

Player data.name: Gheorghe Popescu
Player data.bio: Played all of Romania's matches in three World Cups while also appearing for a string of major club teams across Europe. A calm, reassuring, technical presence in the centre of defence

Player data.name: Sol Campbell
Player data.bio: Heroic centre-back remembered by England fans for having goals dramatically disallowed in both 1998 and 2000. A fixture in the defence during two tournaments, making only one substitute appearance in 2006

Player data.name: Carles Puyol
Player data.bio: Shaggy-maned mainstay of the Spanish backline through three tournaments, playing 14 matches and winning in 2010, when he also scored the winner in the semi-final and was named in the all-star team

Player data.name: Roberto Ayala
Player data.bio: Played throughout Argentina's runs to the quarter-finals in 1998 and 2006. Was in the squad in 2002 but was injured during the warm-up for Argentina's opening game and ruled out of the remainder of the tournament. Known as El Raton – The Mouse – the elegant centre-half was named in the team of the tournament in 2006

Player data.name: Bellini
Player data.bio: Captain of Brazil's first World Cup-winners, whose statue stands outside the Maracaña. A rugged if slight defender who played to his strengths, Bellini was named in the all-star team in 1958 but was also a member of Brazil's squads in 1962, when he did not play, and 1966, when he captained the team through two of their group games

Player data.name: John Terry
Player data.bio: National anthem-blaring, rugged, chest-beating heart of the England defence in two World Cups. Named in the all-star team in 2006

Player data.name: Lucio
Player data.bio: Tall, commanding centre-back who picked up a winner's medal in 2002 and set a Fifa record in 2006 by playing for 386 consecutive minutes without conceding a foul

Player data.name: Carlos Gamarra
Player data.bio: Tower of strength in Paraguay's defence through three World Cups, and their most capped player of all time. Though Paraguay lost to France in the second round in 1998 Gamarra was widely praised, not conceding a single foul in the entire tournament and being named in Fifa's all-star team. He excelled again in 2002, and retired after the 2006 tournament, in which he was credited with an ultimately decisive own goal in the 1-0 defeat by England

Player data.name: Thomas N'Kono
Player data.bio: Went to three World Cups and is arguably the greatest goalkeeper Africa has ever produced. Part of the team that stunned Argentina in the opening match of the 1990 World Cup

Player data.name: Iker Casillas
Player data.bio: Hugely experienced goalkeeper who played in his first World Cup in 2002 and immediately made his mark by saving two penalties in the shoot-out against the Republic of Ireland. A World Cup winner in South Africa in 2010

Player data.name: Harald Schumacher
Player data.bio: Earned a place in any all-time hall of shame for his foul on Patrick Battiston in 1982, but he played superbly in 1986, even captaining the team as they reached the final

Player data.name: Antonio Carbajal
Player data.bio: Nicknamed “El Cinco Copas” – the five cups – because he appeared in five World Cups, playing three times in 1950, once in 1994, three times in 1958, three times in 1962 and once in 1966

Player data.name: Ihor Belanov
Player data.bio: On his way to winning the Golden Ball as Europe’s best player in 1986, Belanov was a star of the World Cup, scoring four goals (he only managed eight in his entire 33-game international career), including a peach against Belgium, and setting up another six

Player data.name: Dragan Stojkovic
Player data.bio: Ludicrously talented if tragically injury-prone dribbler, free-kick taker and playmaker who scored three goals in nine matches across two World Cups, shining most brightly in 1990, particularly with a second-round match-winning brace against Spain
